text: looking up our moon from Earth it's a
gloriously pristine disc of reflected
light but nearly 400,000 kilometers of
space is enough to hide a dirty secret
on its surface we have been visiting our
celestial neighbor since the late 1950s
and we've taken over a little bit more
than just a welcoming plate of cookies
we have sent probes and satellites and
of course humans to take a closer look
and many of these space missions took
more than photos and left more than just
footprints in the early days of the
space race during the 1960's the US and
USSR were sending up increasingly bigger
rockets and payloads in preparation of
becoming the first nation to put a man
on the moon
many of these crashed some intentionally
to be honest onto the moon's surface
others landed in one piece and sent back
all important information that paved the
way for future missions then as we all
know in 1969 two American men stepped
out of the Apollo 11 descent module and
became the first to walk on the surface
of the Moon further manned missions
followed along with more spacecraft and
even though the space race is now long
over agencies are still sending
instruments to study every aspect of the
moon and the thing is pretty much all of
those bits and bobs that we've sent over
the last sixty years are still their
mangled remains of the earliest
spaceships burn out rocket boosters even
the iconic descent stage of Apollo 11
the moon hosts the wreckage of nearly
seventeen space vehicles getting there
was the priority once the vehicles job
was done they were simply abandoned
admittedly it nearly half a million
clicks is a long way to go just to pick
up a few bits of metal but the lunar
littering doesn't end there a total of
12 people have set foot on the moon on
six separate missions but these missions
weren't just sightseeing Jones the crews
were given a rigorous schedule of
scientific experiments to complete
taking measurements and collecting
samples and to be able to get those
valuable samples off the moon's surface
the astronauts had to jettison pretty
much everything that they didn't need
anymore
meaning loads of really awesome
hardware was simply left behind there
are three lunar Rovers for instance and
they've driven more than 90 kilometers
albeit speed of just 13 kph they were
designed to carry two astronauts and
plenty of rock samples but that has made
them too big and too heavy to bring home
it wasn't just the big stuff that was
abandoned either anything that wasn't
needed for the return journey was at
risk of being chucked out the tools they
used to collect the samples the TV
cameras that filmed their lunar
activities insulating blankets utility
towels and personal hygiene kits empty
food packets even six pairs of space
boots around a hundred pieces of litter
were left from just the first moon
landing alone perhaps the most unsavory
flotsam and jetsam are the 96 or so
packages of human urine and feces and
vomit sea missions could last several
days and when you gotta go you gotta go
and you can kind of see why they
wouldn't have wanted to make the return

luggage not everything that was left
behind was out of necessity though what
better way to leave your mark on a moon
than to literally leave something to
mark your visit the most obvious are
those patriotic American flags six in
total planted by each of the Apollo
crews to make it to the surface only
five are left standing though since the
first one placed by Neil Armstrong Buzz
Aldrin of Apollo 11 was blown down as
their spacecraft blasted off home whoops
Apollo 11 left a few other symbolic
items as well there was a plaque bearing
the signatures of the crew and
commemorating the first moon landing a
golden olive branch to symbolize peace
for all mankind and a small silicon disk
only slightly bigger than a 50 P piece
which has messages from 73 world leaders
etched on it in letters a quarter of the
width of a human hair but it wasn't all
peace patriotism and goodwill Apollo 16
astronaut Charles Duke left a photograph
of his family while Alan Shepard took a
break from his duties on the Apollo 14
mission to drive a couple of golf balls
across the lunar surface with a foldable
6-iron that
smuggled along in a sock there's art to
a small aluminium statue called the
fallen astronaut was placed by the crew
of Apollo 15 to commemorate the
Americans and Russians that died in the
scramble to reach the moon during the
space race there's a tiny ceramic chip
the size of a penny that bears doodles
from artists of the time including Andy
Warhol now his is an interesting
contribution it could be his signature
or a spaceship but it does look an awful
lot like a certain male appendage so
Bravo mr. Warhol you've got the first
penis doodle on the moon in total the

and symbolic paraphernalia make up
